thread.title: Redwood comes up a little short, falls 28-26
thread.title_full: Redwood comes up a little short, falls 28-26

title: Redwood comes up a little short, falls 28-26
text:
Redwood comes up a little short, falls 28-26 Redwood (1-6, 1-2) had a Hail Mary-attempt from the Hanford 38 with three seconds left. Post to Facebook Redwood comes up a little short, falls 28-26 Redwood (1-6, 1-2) had a Hail Mary-attempt from the Hanford 38 with three seconds left. Check out this story on visaliatimesdelta.com: http://vtd-tar.co/1Lna7aR Cancel Send A link has been sent to your friend's email address. Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. Join the Conversation Andrew Bettencourt, abettenc@visaliatimesdelta.com 11:48 p.m. PDT October 9, 2015 Redwood’s Michael Bean tries to get past Hanford’s Will Pepe during Friday’s game. Hanford won 28-26. (Photo: Johanna Coyne) 20 CONNECT 8 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
If there were any outside the Redwood Ranger football program who thought the Rangers had a reasonable shot at upending the state-ranked Hanford Bullpups, it had to be a very select few — emphasis on few. 
General thinking was that Redwood was going to need an avalanche of big plays to have any chance of taking down Hanford. 
Redwood received the required bevy of big plays. 
Unfortunately, the Rangers needed one more than they recorded to pull off the Central Section’s biggest upset of the season. 
Hanford survived Redwood’s major upset bid with a 28-26 decision over the Rangers Friday night at Giant Chevrolet-Cadillac Mineral King Bowl. 
“I’m not big on moral victories, but I thought our team played really well,” Redwood coach Shaun Ball said. “This is the kind of game that showed the level we’re capable of playing, especially defensively. If we can close the season playing this well, we’re going to be okay.” 
How close were the Rangers to pulling off the upset? 
Redwood (1-6, 1-2) had a Hail Mary-attempt from the Hanford 38 with three seconds on the clock. The pass fell to the ground a couple of yards shy of the goal line to end the game. 
This contest was supposed to be a showcase of Hanford’s overall prowess. 
The Bullpups are ranked No. 7 in CalHiSports.com’s state-wide CIF Division III poll. Hanford entered Friday with a Central Section-leading 45.5 points-per-game scoring average. 
The Bullpups hardly looked like a team capable of playing for a CIF state bowl championship on Friday. 
Hanford had six turnovers — four lost fumbles and two interceptions. 
What almost cost Hanford its bid for a perfect season was coughing up the ball three times on lost fumbles in the fourth quarter. 
The Bullpups’ last two lost fumbles — both forced by impressive play from the Redwood defense —allowed the Rangers to cut Hanford’s 28-14 late fourth-quarter lead to 28-26 with 3:22 remaining in regulation. 
Redwood sophomore Alonzo Ozuna returned one fumble 87 yards for a touchdown. A 65-yard fumble return by Ranger defensive end Patrick Vega set up a five-yard touchdown run by quarterback Frankie Ayon. 
The 28 points was one off the Bullpups’ season-low (a 27-21 win over Porterville on Sept. 18). 
“Our defense the last two weeks has been absolutely phenomenal,” Ball said. “On offense, we just need to do a better job of executing at key moments. But the defense has been something else. I can’t even explain it. They’ve been after it.” 
Despite its bouts with ineptitude from time to time, Hanford had more than enough offensive firepower to generate four touchdowns, three of them on plays of 39 yards or more. 
Hanford junior quarterback Ryan Johnson was 14-of-24 passing for 229 yards and two touchdowns. His scoring passes were an 82-yard bomb to Brandon Sanchez for the Bullpups’ first score and a 39-yard hook-up with Leonard Glass late in the third quarter for their last score. 
Bullpup star running back Joseph McDaniel had a game-high 172 yards rushing on 29 carries. His best run of the night was a 52-yard scoring jaunt that tied the game at 14-14 with 8:55 left in the second quarter. 
Hanford’s up-tempo, spread offense produced a significant disparity in number of plays and total yards. 
Hanford reeled off 81 plays from scrimmage, and Redwood had 52. The Bullpups more than doubled the Rangers’ yardage — 496 to 223. 
Still, there was not a moment in the game where Hanford looked like the superior team without any question. 
Redwood seized a 14-0 lead midway in the first quarter. The Rangers orchestrated a nine-play, 98-yard scoring drive on their first possession — the key play was a 74-yard run by Michael Bean — capped by a two-yard touchdown pass from Frankie Ayon to Brayden Melvin. 
On the Bullpups’ ensuing possession, Redwood’s Cooper Allen snared a tipped pass and returned the interception 22 yards for a touchdown. 
Where the Rangers had their troubles was taking advantage of some earlier Hanford miscues. 
If you were to take away Bean’s long run on Redwood’s first touchdown drive, the Rangers had 34 yards of offense in the first half on 27 plays. 
Bean had a team-high 120 yards on 20 carries. Ayon was 9-of-21 passing for 54 yards to go with 51 yards rushing on nine carries. 
Hanford
